metadata.title: Ulnar Nerve Entrapment Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Ulnar nerve (at the elbow or wrist), ring and little fingers, intrinsic hand muscles, finger flexors, wrist flexors

ICD-10 codes.G56.2: lesion of ulnar nerve (ICD codes are provided for the reader's reference only, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement for initial treatment of UN entrapment syndrome has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Chronic intermittent or continuous paresthesias (aching, tingling, numbness) in the ulnar half of the 4th and the 5th digit
If UN-supplied  intrinsic hand muscles are involved,“clumsiness” related to finger numbness and hand palsy (e.g., ring and small digit clawing; loss of first dorsal interosseous)
In cubital tunnel syndrome, a dull ache in the medial elbow and forearm may be felt along with a tingling sensation that radiates from medial side of forearm to the 5th and ulnar aspect 4th digit
With compression in Guyon’s canal, symptoms may be pure motor, pure sensory, or mixed, depending upon the location of compression within the canal
In ulnar tunnel syndrome, paresthesias involve only the hand
Nocturnal numbness may occur when sleeping with elbow flexed past 90°
Postoperative therapy may not be required. Significant weakness or pain after surgery may indicate a need for rehabilitation Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Bony anomalies or soft tissue space-occupying  lesions (e.g., scar, adhesion, cyst) that narrow the involved cubital or ulnartunnel may predispose to UN entrapment with repetitive elbow and/or wrist flexion(21)

Activities that might overstretch or compress the UN are implicated (e.g., throwing sports, playing certain musicalinstruments, weight-bearing  on bent elbows or extended wrists, biking, repetitive use of pliers, knitting).(11,19,20)Baseballpitchers often have hypertrophied flexor-pronator  muscle mass, which can compress the UN at the elbow(14)
Blunt trauma to the cubital tunnel or ulnar tunnel can cause swelling, which can then impinge onto the nerve

Direct compression of the deep terminal motor branch at the Guyon’s canal can cause palsy of the intrinsic UN-suppliedhand muscles, as in “handlebar palsy” or permanent “claw hand” of bicycle riders(2,19)
pathogenesis: As in other mononeuropathies, UN entrapment symptoms depend on the extent of nerve damage and if both the sensoryand the motor fibers within the nerve or nerve branches are involved

The severity of symptoms in cubital tunnel syndrome may depend on the degree of UN swelling, compression, or type ofentrapment–Authors of a study in in Iran found that in patients with cubital tunnel syndrome confirmed with electrodiagnostic testing,the cross-sectional  area measured by diagnostic ultrasound of the UN at the medial epicondyle and 2 cm distal to themedial epicondyle was significantly larger than in a normal control group of individuals(4)

Causes of UN compression at Guyon’s canal include:(19)–ganglion cyst or tumor–hamate hook fracture–repetitive trauma (e.g., compression from handlebars)–muscular anomaly–ulnar artery thrombosis or aneurysm (e.g., hypothenar hammer syndrome)
risk factors: Upper extremity activities that increase the risk of UN entrapment involve–direct pressure on the UN; e.g., cyclists are at risk of handlebar palsy from bearing weight on the palm or of cubital tunnelsyndrome from bearing weight on bent elbows when using aero extension bars(2)–overstretching (and possible subluxation) of the UN in the cubital tunnel–prolonged elbow flexion past 90° (e.g., driving, sleeping, typing)–repetitive elbow flexion (e.g., using a drill press, lifting, carrying)

Authors of a birth cohort study (N = 8,718) in Finland found that smoking was correlated with development of UNentrapment.Sex, obesity, and socioeconomic status were not associated with UNentrapment(5)

Authors of a cross-sectional  study (N = 40) found prevalenceof ulnar neuropathy of 27.5% in patients receivinghemodialysis and 25% in those receiving peritoneal dialysis. The risk is thought to be due to the positioning of the upperextremity during treatment and underlying polyneuropathy(6)

overall contraindications precautions: Because overstretching and compression are implicated as etiologic factors, avoid increasing tension or pressure on the UN with manual techniques (e.g., soft-tissue  mobilization, upper limb tension testing)(7)
Restrict or modify ADLs, sports, and work activities involving elbow/hand positions and movements that provoke symptoms
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When did symptoms begin? What has been the general progression of the symptoms? Documentany repetitive activities that can compress or stretch the UN. Was there any direct trauma to the elbow? (The term tardy ulnar palsy is used when symptoms develop very slowly after elbow injury)

course of treatment.medical management: Have orthosis use, activity modification, or medications been trialed?
surgical management: Surgical management:  What procedures, if any, have been performed?
course of treatment.medications: What medications (e.g., corticosteroid injection, anti-inflammatory  drugs) have been tried? Are oral medications being taken? Are they effective?
diagnostic tests completed: assess the elbow and wrist to rule out a possible fracture
assess cervical spine and chest if suspicious of the cause of neurological symptoms (i.e., if it is of central origin)
In patients with diabetes, blood tests to exclude polyneuropathy
MRI to rule out tumors and cysts
Diagnostic ultrasound may be used to confirm the entrapment of the UN at the cubital tunnel(16,23)
Electrophysiological studies to assess the degree of UN damage and course of recovery
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Ask about the onset of symptoms (sudden or gradual), quality/intensity/duration of pain, the effect on daily activities, aggravating factors, and alleviating factors
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Is there weakness or incoordination present?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if the  pain  is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. -Does the patient sleep with the involved elbow flexed? -Does the patient wake up with increased symptoms?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any known respiratory compromise? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any prior elbow or hand problems, fractures, or surgery? Any neck problems or injury? Any history of other neuropathy?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other conditions, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient use an orthosis/splint? Do symptoms affect occupational or recreational activities? What involvement of elbow and wrist activities is required by the patient’s job?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Which work or daily activities contribute to symptoms? Sleep position?
social and occupational history.living environment: Inquire about the layout of the home. Identify any barriers to independence in the home and the modifications necessary

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  A comprehensive review is available on clinical testing techniques for suspected ulnar neuropathy(8)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate orthosis for proper fit. Assess elbow/hand function with orthosis on and off. Are any devices indicated due to lack of hand function? With motor involvement, an “anti-claw”  orthosis may be appropriate
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess dynamic balance reactions, as indicated, if the use of the affected arm is limitedAssess the efficiency of movements during aggravating activities and work simulation, if indicated
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess radial and ulnar pulses at the wrist; capillary filling in the affected hand should be normalAssess the dynamic mobility of the upper quadrant with special attention to the UN and compare bilaterally(11)Assess whether transfers are limited by weight-bearing  restrictions, as indicatedAssess accessory motion of ulnar and radiocarpal joints and intercarpal joints as indicatedAssess motor function (coordination) of the upper extremity, as indicated –Fine motor control can be assessed using the 9-hole  peg test –Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test(13)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess muscle tone and strength by manual muscle testing (MMT) of the involved upper extremity (e.g., flexor carpiulnaris)finger spread, extension of 4th and 5th digits at metacarpal phalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints; thumb squeeze against the base of 2nd digit(8) –Use a dynamometer and pinch gauge to measure hand and finger grip strength (compare results bilaterally and appropriately for sex/age) –General muscle strength assessment(8)C8, T1, ulnarC7–8,  radialC7–T1,  median and ulnarC8, T1, ulnarC8, T1, medianC8, medianC6–8,  radialC6–7,  medianC5–6, radialC6–7, medianC–6, musculocutaneousC6–8,  radialC5–6,  axillary
observation inspection palpation includi: Abduction (“Wartenberg’s sign”) of the small finger or clawing of the ring and small fingers with the extension of the fingers is associated with severe UN injury

Assess the integrity of skin in UN distribution area for dryness (flaking, scaling), redness, and irritation. Assess for trophic changes associated with chronic regional pain syndrome, if present, and for proper fitting of the orthosis

A hollowed appearance of the hand (e.g., atrophy of the first dorsal interosseous and abductor digitiquinti) is indicative of motor involvement •Palpation:  Examine palm of the hand for atrophy of hypothenar eminence and intrinsic hand muscles.(11) Deep palpation (“pressure test”) of cubital tunnel and the ulnar tunnel may provoke symptoms. Also, Tinel’s sign may be elicited by light tapping over the UN
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess alignment at elbow and wrist; complete a general upper body postural assessment as indicated
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Measure active and passive ROM at elbow, wrist, and digits using a goniometer. Check for subluxation of UN from cubital tunnel on passive overpressure in elbow flexion. Compare to the uninvolved side –Complete a cervical screen to assess for loss of ROM or impairment in this region, since the impact on the UN may stem from this location as well(8)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess upper extremity deep tendon reflexesDetermine whether there are deficits in hand function/dexterity that may impair personal care. Ask the patient to demonstrate daily activities that provoke the symptoms. Do these activities involve repetitive elbow flexion or increase pressure on the palm of the hand? –The Manual Ability Measure (MAM) can be used to assess upper extremity function for ADLs(17,18)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess sensation (pinprick, light touch, temperature) in distribution of UN (i.e., ulnar side of hand proximal to 5th digit, small digit, and ulnar aspect of ring finger) (e.g., Semmes-Weinstein  Monofilaments, Weinstein Enhanced Sensory Test [WEST]). Expect positive Tinel’s and compression signs with percussion at cubital tunnel or UN tunnel, and reduced sensation over the volar aspect of hand(8)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosispatient holds a sheet of paper between the thumb and radial aspect of the index finger (lateral pinch) while examiner pulls on the sheet (positive if flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint of the thumb is observed). Palpate the first dorsal interosseous to assess for atrophyDoes static elbow hyperflexion for 1 minute provoke symptoms?Percussion of UN provokes a visible muscular jerk in myotome(8)

contraindications precautions: Over an area of nerve regrowth
Do not place electrodes near: -carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads
In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen
In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck
History of spontaneous abortion in pregnant women
over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
in an area with infection or bleeding
if a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
in the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
Ineffective communication skills in a patient (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications; do not use:(9)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: UN entrapment syndrome/paresthesias and possible weakness in the distribution of the UN that reduce sensation and motor function of the involved hand; patient education for modification or avoidance of provocative activities; postoperative surgical repair; hand therapy to improve functional deficits
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Carpal tunnel syndrome (distinguishing symptoms from UN entrapment syndrome involve first 3 digits and nocturnal pain) Wartenberg’s radial neuritis (sensory only and does not involve 4th or 5th fingers) Cervical radiculitis (the main feature is neck pain/trauma) Raynaud’s syndrome (all fingers cold and present with a blue tint) Thoracic outlet syndrome (if shoulder position aggravates the symptoms) Cervical cord compression (bilateral symptoms) Diabetic polyneuropathy Chronic regional pain syndrome
prognosis: Research is lacking to determine optimal surgical intervention. In addition the only clinical scenario in which a majority of member surgeons surveyed by the American Society for Surgery of the Hand favor nonoperative treatment is in patients with normal EMG/NCS and no weakness or atrophy of interosseous muscles(10)
It is also reasonable to expect improved function after hand strengthening
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Back to referring physician if there is no functional improvement To neurosurgeon as indicated
treatment summary: No clinical trials are available to guide physical or occupational therapy interventions in UN entrapment syndrome. Optimal management will vary from case to case.(11) Patient education related to positioning and avoidance of exacerbating activities are key components of nonoperative treatment(3)

Conservative treatment generally involves symptom management, forearm and hand strengthening and stretching as indicated, orthosis use, patient education, and facilitation of the return to normal ADLs

Authors of a systematic review of treatment for ulnar neuropathy at the elbow who compared nonoperative to operative treatment found insufficient evidence to identify the best treatment. With regard to surgical procedures, simple  decompression and decompression with ulnar nerve transposition were found to be equally effective in idiopathic ulnar neuropathy at the elbow(22) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Paresthesias/pain Reduce or resolve symptomsActivity modification _ Implement changes to help reduce symptoms associated with provoking activities (e.g., headset for phone use; avoid resting arm on medial elbow in the car) _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Trial of elbow or wrist orthosis in a neutral position,(19,20,21) towel roll to limit elbow flexion when sleeping(2) _ Physical agents and mechanical modalities _ Trial of iontophoresis or phonophoresis with dexamethasone for pain management as indicated and ordered by the physician _ _ Cryotherapy may be tried for pain managementGradual reduction in symptomsEducation the patient in activity modification, positioning, and orthosis use  Wrist/hand weakness Increase strength and prevent atrophyTherapeutic exercises _ Comparative methods of hand/wrist strengthening exercises in this syndrome have not been reported. Therefore, therapeutic strengthening and dexterity exercises should be guided by the evaluation on a case- by-case basis(11) _ _ To gently stretch the UN, instruct the patient to depress shoulder, laterally rotate and abduct shoulder, flex elbow, supinate forearm, place wrist in extension, and flex neck laterally away from the affected side(11) _ _ Electrotherapeutic modalities _ Electric stimulation can be applied to reduce or prevent atrophy(12)Progress each patient as appropriate and indicatedImplement a home exercise program with written and verbal instruction  Decreased ability to complete daily activities _Restore functional capacity _ _Functional training _ Instruction on alternative methods to complete ADLs _ Instruction in use of adaptive equipment to increase independence in self-care activities (e.g., use of a wash mitt if clawing limits the ability to hold a washcloth) _ _ Dexterity/coordination activities _ _ Refer to occupational therapy or hand therapy if necessaryPatient should gradually return to prior ADLs/sports _ _ Incorporate and progress functional training as indicatedEducate the patient on aggravating factors and provide activities helpful for increasing functional status Reduced elbow/wrist/ hand flexibility after surgery or prolonged splintingIncrease elbow/wrist/ hand ROMPostoperative therapeutic exercises _ Use of stretching techniques to mobilize the affected joint and increase the ROM lost due to surgery or prolonged immobilization _ _ Instruct the patient on how to complete active ROM and self- stretchingROM of the affected joint should gradually increase with continued therapyAfter patient education, may implement a home program of safe stretches Reduced nerve dynamic mobility of the upper quadrantIncrease neural dynamic mobilityManual therapy Mobilize the UN and other restricted elements of the upper quadrant. Utilize either the gliding or tension technique, as appropriateProgress to tension technique if gliding neural mobilization technique is initially startedIncorporate neural mobilization exercises into the home exercise program .

increased elbow, wrist, and hand functio: Hand surgeons commonly use the McGowan grading system to assess status and gauge outcome(3,15)–Grade I: intermittent paresthesias in the ulnar distribution; reports of clumsiness with the affected hand; no detectablehand weakness or atrophy–Grade II: sensory loss and measurably weak lumbrical and interossei musculature–Grade III: severe sensory and motor deficits and muscle wasting

maintenance or prevention: Continued avoidance of activities and positions that aggravate symptoms for self-management  of pain
patient education: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons website: “Ulnar Nerve Entrapment at the Elbow (Cubital Tunnel Syndrome)” at https://orthoinfo.aaos.org/en/diseases--conditions/ulnar-nerve-entrapment-at-the-elbow-cubital-tunnel-syndrome
American Society of Hand Therapistswebsite: “Cubital Tunnel” at https://www.asht.org/sites/default/files/docs/2018/Cubital %20Tunnel%20Syndrome%202018.pdf

American Academy of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitationwebsite: “Ulnar Nerve Mononeuropathy at the Wrist” at https://now.aapmr.org/ulnar-nerve-mononeuropathy-at-the-wrist-2/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
